keyTakeAways: A major heist occurred at the Louvre Museum in Paris on Sunday, October 20, 2025, where nine valuable historical artifacts were stolen from the Apollo Gallery in just seven minutes.
The stolen items include a sapphire diadem, an emerald necklace and earrings gifted by Napoleon to Marie-Louise, a reliquary brooch and a diamond bow brooch from Empress Eugénie’s collection.

The sapphire diadem was originally worn by queens including Hortense de Beauharnais, Marie-Amélie, and Isabelle d’Orléans and once belonged to the Orléans family before being acquired by the Louvre in 1985.
The emerald necklace and earrings were a 1810 wedding gift from Napoleon to Marie-Louise and were preserved and sold to the Louvre in 2004 for 3.7 million euros.
The reliquary brooch, crafted for Empress Eugénie in 1855 by Paul-Alfred Bapst, contains the 17th and 18th Mazarin diamonds, originally given to Louis XIV by Cardinal Mazarin in 1661.

The diamond bow brooch was once part of a 4,000-stone belt worn by Eugénie during visits to Versailles and was later transformed into a standalone brooch, sold in 1887 to Caroline Astor, and acquired by the Louvre in 2008 for 6.72 million euros.
A pearl diadem made for Eugénie in 1853 contains 212 pearls and 1,998 diamonds.
One of the most significant stolen items — Empress Eugénie’s crown — was recovered near the scene, though it was damaged during the heist.

Art expert Arthur Brand described the theft as a 'national disaster' for France, noting that the stolen items are symbols of national pride and are likely to be dismantled and sold due to their high value.
The thieves broke into two high-security cases using a rapid, coordinated attack and fled on motorcycles, indicating a sophisticated and well-planned heist.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In a major national disaster for France, thieves stole nine high-value historical artifacts from the Louvre Museum’s Apollo Gallery in Paris on Sunday, October 20, 2025, during a seven-minute heist. The stolen items include a sapphire diadem, an emerald necklace and earrings from Napoleon to Marie-Louise, and several pieces from Empress Eugénie’s collection, such as a reliquary brooch and a diamond bow brooch. The crown of Empress Eugénie was targeted but recovered near the scene, though damaged. Experts like Arthur Brand describe the theft as a profound loss of national heritage, as these items represent key pieces of French royal history and are likely to be dismantled and sold. The items were crafted by renowned 19th-century jewelers, including François-Régnault Nitot, Paul-Alfred Bapst, and Alexandre-Gabriel Lemonnier, and had complex histories of ownership, including periods in private hands and institutions like Van Cleef & Arpels and the Smithsonian. The theft has sparked widespread concern over the security of cultural treasures and the global value of French historical artifacts.
